choices.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient presents with the following laboratory values:

 

 

Which of the following best describes the patient’s acid–base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis


Option C: 

 

  1. Anion Gap (AG): AG = Na – (Cl + HCO₃) = 138 – (112 + 8) = 18 (Normal ~12 → Elevated AG indicates anion gap metabolic acidosis.)
  2. Delta Gap (ΔAG): ΔAG = AG_actual – AG_normal = 18 – 12 = 6
  3. Expected Drop in HCO₃ if Only AG Acidosis: ~6 mEq/L
  4. Actual Drop in HCO₃: 24 – 8 = 16 mEq/L
  5. Delta–Delta Ratio: (ΔAG / ΔHCO₃) = 6 / 16 ≈ 0.38 (<1), indicating a second metabolic acidosis (normal anion gap) in addition to the high anion gap acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: Does not account for the extra bicarbonate drop.


Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis: Would typically yield a higher bicarbonate, often with Δ–Δ > 2.


Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: The elevated AG of 18 rules out a pure normal AG acidosis.


Educational Objective:

 

When you see a low bicarbonate and an elevated anion gap, use the Delta–Delta Ratio. A ratio <1 suggests coexisting anion gap and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Top of Form

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid–base status
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

 

Option D:

 

The pH is high (7.55), indicating alkalosis. The bicarbonate is significantly elevated (45 mEq/L), suggesting a primary metabolic alkalosis. In response, the body compensates by hypoventilating, thus increasing the PCO₂ to 53 mm Hg. A useful formula to estimate respiratory compensation in metabolic alkalosis is:


Expected PaCO₂ (mm Hg) ≈ 0.7 × [HCO₃⁻] + 20 ± 5


Substituting 45 mEq/L for HCO₃⁻ gives (0.7 × 45) + 20 = 31.5 + 20 = 51.5 ± 5 mm Hg. Because the actual PCO₂ (53 mm Hg) lies within that range, this confirms metabolic alkalosis with an appropriate respiratory (hypoventilatory) compensation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis would present with a low pH (acidemia) and high PCO₂, not alkalemia.

 

Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis would show a high pH but a low PCO₂.

 

Option C. Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation typically results in a less elevated pH; 7.55 is too alkalotic for that scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high bicarbonate and alkalemic pH accompanied by an elevated, appropriately compensated PCO₂ is characteristic of metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation.

choices.text: Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap
Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with chronic liver disease is admitted for worsening abdominal distension. His laboratory findings are as follows:

 

  • Sodium (Na⁺): 140 mEq/L
  • Chloride (Cl⁻): 115 mEq/L
  • Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 26 mEq/L
  • Albumin: 1.2 g/dL

 

Which of the following best explains the anion gap?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap

 

Option B:

 

The anion gap is calculated as:
Anion Gap (AG)=Na⁺−(Cl⁻+HCO₃⁻) 
AG=140−(115+26)=140−141=−1 mEq/L
In this patient, the anion gap is near zero, which is abnormally low. Albumin, a major unmeasured anion, contributes significantly to the anion gap. For every 1 g/dL decrease in serum albumin (normal ~4 g/dL), the anion gap decreases by approximately 2.5 mEq/L.


With this patient's albumin of 1.2 g/dL, the anion gap is reduced by:
Reduction in AG=(4−1.2)×2.5=7 mEq/L 
The expected corrected anion gap would be approximately 6–8 mEq/L (within the low-normal range after accounting for hypoalbuminemia). Therefore, the low anion gap is adequately explained by hypoalbuminemia in this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Laboratory error in chloride measurement is unlikely because the sodium, chloride, and bicarbonate levels are consistent with normal measurement trends.


Option C. Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma can reduce the anion gap through excess cationic monoclonal proteins, but this patient has no evidence of multiple myeloma, and hypoalbuminemia is a more likely explanation.


Option D. Metabolic alkalosis does not typically result in a low anion gap. It may raise bicarbonate, but that does not account for the reduction in the anion gap observed here.

 

Educational Objective:


The anion gap is significantly influenced by albumin levels. Hypoalbuminemia decreases the anion gap by reducing unmeasured anions. In this case, the corrected anion gap appropriately accounts for the low albumin, ruling out other causes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever and altered mental status. On examination, his blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 134/min. He has crackles over the left infrascapular region. Lab results are as follows: Na⁺: 138 mEq/L, Cl⁻: 98 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻: 10 mEq/L, BUN: 58 mg/dL, Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL, Blood glucose: 180 mg/dL. Which of the following best explains the anion gap?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Accumulation of lactate

 

Option D:

 

The anion gap (AG) = Na − (Cl + HCO₃) = 138 − (98 + 10) = 30, which is markedly elevated. The patient’s hypotension and fever suggest septic shock, commonly causing lactic acidosis due to tissue hypoperfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Excessive administration of normal saline: Causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) acidosis, not an elevated one.


Option B. Ketone body production: Are less likely because the glucose of 180 mg/dL is not highly suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, and the clinical picture points more toward sepsis.


Option C. Hyperchloremia: Results in Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis

 

Educational Objective:


In a hypotensive, septic patient, a high anion gap metabolic acidosis most often indicates lactic acidosis secondary to poor tissue perfusion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with hypokalemia and recurrent kidney stones presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. His urinary anion gap is measured and found to be positive. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low NH₄⁺ excretion

 

Option B:

 

The urinary anion gap (Na⁺ + K⁺ – Cl⁻) is used to estimate urinary ammonium (NH₄⁺) excretion in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. A positive urinary anion gap suggests inadequate (low) NH₄⁺ excretion, indicating a renal acidification defect, such as distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Hypokalemia and recurrent kidney stones further support a renal cause of the acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Excess NH₄⁺ excretion: Would cause a negative urinary anion gap, more typical of GI bicarbonate loss rather than a renal defect.


Option C. High urinary chloride: Alone does not necessarily produce a positive urinary anion gap; in fact, increased urinary chloride often makes the gap more negative or closer to zero.


Option D. Excessive urinary acidification: Is not consistent with a positive urinary anion gap; with adequate NH₄⁺ excretion and acidification, the gap would be negative.

 

Educational Objective:


A positive urinary anion gap in a patient with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis typically indicates low NH₄⁺ excretion and points to a renal rather than GI cause of the acidosis (e.g., distal RTA).

choices.text: Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic respiratory acidosis

 

Option D:

 

The low pH (7.34) indicates acidemia. The elevated PCO₂ (60 mmHg) suggests a respiratory acidosis, and the elevated bicarbonate (31 mEq/L) reflects renal compensation, which occurs only in chronic conditions.

 

Compensation for Chronic Respiratory Acidosis:

 

  1. Change in PaCO₂:
    Observed PaCO₂ = 60 mmHg
    Normal PaCO₂ = 40 mmHg
    Change in PaCO₂ = 60 - 40 = 20 mmHg
  2. Bicarbonate Compensation:
    For chronic respiratory acidosis, bicarbonate increases by 4 mEq/L for every 10 mmHg rise in PaCO₂.
    Calculation: 20/10×4=8 mEq/L
  3. Expected Bicarbonate Level:
    Normal bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L
    Expected bicarbonate = 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L
  4. Conclusion:
    The observed bicarbonate level (31 mEq/L) is close to the expected value (32 mEq/L), confirming chronic respiratory acidosis with renal compensation.

 

This confirms chronic respiratory acidosis with renal compensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis would present with a low bicarbonate and compensatory low PCO₂, not elevated PCO₂.


Option B. Acute respiratory acidosis: Incorrect because bicarbonate is elevated, indicating renal compensation, which occurs only in chronic conditions.


Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because the elevated bicarbonate rules out a primary metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic respiratory acidosis occurs with prolonged CO₂ retention, leading to renal compensation by increasing bicarbonate. Differentiating acute from chronic respiratory acidosis requires assessing bicarbonate levels, which increase significantly only in chronic conditions.

choices.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anion gap metabolic acidosis

 

Option A:

 

The patient has a pH of 7.23, indicating acidemia. The PCO₂ of 25 mmHg is appropriately reduced, consistent with respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis. The anion gap (AG) is calculated as AG = Na⁺ - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻) = 138 - (100 + 10) = 28, indicating an anion gap metabolic acidosis (normal <12). Using the delta ratio helps confirm the presence of a pure anion gap acidosis: ΔAG = measured AG - normal AG = 28 - 12 = 16, and ΔHCO₃⁻ = normal HCO₃⁻ - measured HCO₃⁻ = 24 - 10 = 14. The delta ratio (ΔAG/ΔHCO₃⁻) = 16/14 = 1.14, which is within the expected range (1–2) for a pure anion gap metabolic acidosis. There is no evidence of an additional metabolic alkalosis or normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: Plus metabolic alkalosis is incorrect because there is no elevated bicarbonate or evidence of alkalosis. 

 

Option C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Is incorrect as there is no hyperchloremia to suggest an additional non-anion gap acidosis. 

 

Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Is incorrect as the elevated anion gap clearly indicates an anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delta-delta ratio analysis helps differentiate pure anion gap metabolic acidosis from mixed acid-base disorders. A ratio within the normal range (1–2) confirms a single anion gap metabolic acidosis without additional acid-base disturbances.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis

 

Option C: 

 

The pH of 7.36 indicates compensated acidemia. The low bicarbonate (13 mEq/L) suggests primary metabolic acidosis, while the low PCO₂ (24 mmHg) indicates a coexisting respiratory alkalosis beyond expected compensation. Using Winter’s formula, the expected PCO₂ for pure metabolic acidosis is calculated as:

 

Expected PCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2
Expected PCO₂ = (1.5 × 13) + 8 ± 2 = 27.5 ± 2 (range: 25.5–29.5)

 

The measured PCO₂ of 24 mmHg is lower than expected, indicating a primary respiratory alkalosis in addition to the metabolic acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis: Is incorrect because the PCO₂ is low, not elevated, ruling out respiratory acidosis.


Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis: Is incorrect because the bicarbonate would be elevated due to renal compensation, not reduced.

 

Option D. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: Is incorrect because the PCO₂ is lower than the expected range, indicating an additional primary respiratory alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The delta ratio and Winter’s formula are essential tools for evaluating mixed acid-base disorders. A PCO₂ lower than expected in metabolic acidosis suggests an additional respiratory alkalosis. This highlights the importance of calculating expected compensation to detect hidden mixed disorders.

choices.text: Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis
Chronic metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis

 

Option B:

 

The pH of 7.27 indicates acidemia. The elevated PCO₂ (55 mmHg) suggests a primary respiratory cause (respiratory acidosis). The normal bicarbonate (25 mEq/L) indicates there hasn’t been enough time for renal compensation, which would elevate bicarbonate levels in a chronic process.

 

Using the compensation formula for acute respiratory acidosis:

 

ΔpH = 0.008 × ΔPaCO₂


ΔPaCO₂ = 55 − 40 = 15


ΔpH = 0.008 × 15 = 0.12

 

Expected pH = 7.40 − 0.12 = 7.28.


The measured pH of 7.27 closely matches the expected value, confirming acute respiratory acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis would present with low bicarbonate and compensatory low PCO₂, which are not observed here.


Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because the bicarbonate is normal, ruling out metabolic acidosis.


Option D. Chronic metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation: Incorrect because chronic metabolic acidosis would present with low bicarbonate and low PCO₂ as compensation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute respiratory acidosis is characterized by an acidemic pH, elevated PCO₂, and normal bicarbonate (before compensation occurs). Compensation for respiratory acidosis takes days, so normal bicarbonate suggests an acute process.

choices.text: Acute respiratory alkalosis plus acute metabolic alkalosis
Chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation

 

Option D:

 

The pH of 7.44 is alkalotic, suggesting a primary alkalosis. The low PCO₂ (20 mmHg) indicates a respiratory cause. The low bicarbonate (13 mEq/L) reflects renal compensation, which occurs over time in chronic respiratory alkalosis.

 

Using the provided table:

 

  • In chronic respiratory alkalosis, for every 10 mmHg decrease in PCO₂ below 40 mmHg, bicarbonate decreases by 5 mEq/L.
  • Expected bicarbonate = 24 − [(40 − 20)/10 × 5] = 24 − 10 = 14 mEq/L.

 

The patient’s measured bicarbonate of 13 mEq/L is consistent with expected compensation, confirming chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis: Incorrect, as acidosis would result in a low pH, not the alkalotic pH seen here.


Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect because bicarbonate levels are reduced, indicating renal compensation, which occurs only in chronic conditions.


Option C. Acute respiratory alkalosis plus acute metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect because the bicarbonate is low, ruling out metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic respiratory alkalosis occurs with prolonged hyperventilation, leading to renal compensation by reducing bicarbonate levels. The distinction between acute and chronic respiratory alkalosis is based on bicarbonate levels, which decrease significantly only in chronic conditions.

choices.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

 

Option B:

 

Calculate the anion gap: AG = Na - (Cl + HCO₃⁻) = 140 - (88 + 12) = 40. The anion gap is significantly elevated, indicating anion gap metabolic acidosis (AGMA).

For the delta ratio:

 

ΔAG = Measured AG - Normal AG = 40 - 12 = 28

ΔHCO₃⁻ = Normal HCO₃⁻ - Measured HCO₃⁻ = 24 - 12 = 12

Δ Ratio = ΔAG / ΔHCO₃⁻ = 28 / 12 = 2.33

 

A delta ratio > 2 suggests the presence of concurrent metabolic alkalosis with the anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: This is partially correct but incomplete as it doesn't account for the mixed disorder indicated by the delta ratio > 2.

 

Option C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because the delta ratio > 2 indicates alkalosis, not a second acidosis. In mixed normal gap and high gap acidosis, the delta ratio would be < 1.

 

Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Clearly incorrect as the AG is significantly elevated at 40.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use the delta ratio to identify mixed acid-base disorders. A delta ratio > 2 suggests concurrent metabolic alkalosis along with anion gap metabolic acidosis, which can occur in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis with vomiting or lactic acidosis with diuretic use.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

 

Option D:

 

Winter's formula predicts the expected PCO₂ for primary metabolic acidosis:

 

Expected PCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2


= (1.5 × 14) + 8 ± 2


= 21 ± 2 mm Hg

 

The observed PCO₂ is 35 mm Hg, which is significantly higher than the expected range (19–23 mm Hg). This indicates an additional respiratory acidosis on top of metabolic acidosis, confirming a mixed acid-base disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis: The low bicarbonate and pH indicate metabolic involvement, which excludes isolated acute respiratory acidosis.


Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis: Chronic conditions show higher bicarbonate compensation, which is not present here.


Option C. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: The observed PCO₂ is much higher than predicted by Winter's formula, ruling out appropriate compensation.

 

Educational Objective:


Winter's formula is a crucial tool to differentiate between simple and mixed acid-base disorders in metabolic acidosis. A discrepancy between observed and expected PCO₂ indicates an additional respiratory process.

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings: 

 

  • Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 32 mEq/L 
  • pH: 7.51 
  • PCO₂: 35 mm Hg

 

Which of the following best describes the patient's acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The pH of 7.51 indicates alkalemia (alkalotic state). 
  • The elevated bicarbonate (>24 mEq/L) signifies a primary metabolic alkalosis. 
  • In metabolic alkalosis, the respiratory system typically compensates by increasing 

PCO₂ to help normalize pH. But here the PCO₂ is 35 mm Hg (<40), which is low indicating an independent respiratory alkalosis as well. 

  • Whenever HCO₃⁻ (high in this case) and PCO2 (low in this case), move in opposite directions  it is highly suggestive of a mixed disorder. 

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. Chronic respiratory alkalosis: Usually presents with decreased PCO₂ and a compensatory decrease in bicarbonate (not elevated). The elevated bicarbonate here rules this out. 
  • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis: Typically involves decreased PCO₂ with normal bicarbonate and an elevated pH. Since bicarbonate is grossly elevated here, this does not fit. 
  • Option C. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory acidosis: Respiratory acidosis involves elevated PCO₂, but here PCO₂ is low, so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When HCO₃⁻ and PCO₂ move in opposite directions—it indicates a mixed acid-base disorder.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with severe metabolic acidosis and the following lab results:

 

  • Sodium: 140 mEq/L
  • Chloride: 100 mEq/L
  • Bicarbonate: 8 mEq/L
  • BUN: 56 mg/dL
  • Plasma Glucose: 180 mg/dL
  • Serum Osmolality: 332 mOsm/kg

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methanol poisoning

 

Option A:

 

To determine the most likely cause of the metabolic acidosis, the serum osmolal gap and anion gap are calculated:

 

1. Serum osmolality (calculated):
Formula:

Calculated Osmolality=(2×Na⁺)+BUN2.8+Glucose18

Substituting the values:

(2×140)+562.8+18018=280+20+10=310 mOsm/kg

 

2. Osmolal gap:

Osmolal gap=Measured Osmolality−Calculated Osmolality

Substituting the values:

332−310=22 mOsm/kg

An osmolal gap >10 is significant and suggests the presence of unmeasured osmoles, often seen in toxic alcohol ingestion (e.g., methanol or ethylene glycol).

 

3. Anion gap:
Formula:

Anion gap=Na⁺−(Cl⁻+HCO₃⁻)

Substituting the values:

140−(100+8)=32 mEq/L

A high anion gap confirms metabolic acidosis.

Given the high anion gap, elevated osmolal gap, and absence of hyperglycemia (ruling out DKA) or elevated lactate (ruling out lactic acidosis), methanol poisoning is the most likely cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Typically presents with hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL and does not cause an elevated osmolal gap.


Option C. Lactic acidosis: Would present with elevated lactate levels, and would not present with elevated osmolal gap. 


Option D. Renal failure: Causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to retention of uremic toxins but does not cause an elevated osmolal gap.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with an elevated osmolal gap, toxic alcohol ingestion (e.g., methanol or ethylene glycol) should be strongly suspected. Calculate both gaps to narrow the differential diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with perioral tingling and paresthesias. His blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. His lab results are as follows:

 

  • Sodium: 142 mEq/L
  • Chloride: 110 mEq/L
  • Bicarbonate: 32 mEq/L
  • Urinary chloride: 10 mEq/L

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vomiting

 

Option C: 

 

This patient presents with metabolic alkalosis, evidenced by elevated bicarbonate (32 mEq/L), and low urinary chloride (< 20 mEq/L). This pattern strongly suggests chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis, commonly caused by vomiting or nasogastric suction, which results in hydrochloric acid (HCl) loss.

 

The perioral tingling and paresthesias are likely due to hypocalcemia, caused by alkalosis. In metabolic alkalosis, hydrogen ions are buffered, leading to increased calcium binding to albumin and decreased ionized calcium levels, which trigger neuromuscular symptoms.

 

The low blood pressure (100/60 mm Hg) supports volume depletion due to fluid loss associated with vomiting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Presents with metabolic alkalosis but is associated with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L) due to renal chloride wasting. Blood pressure is usually normal or low.

 

Option B. Gitelman syndrome: Also causes metabolic alkalosis with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L). It typically includes hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria, which are not described here.

 

Option D. Primary aldosteronism: Causes metabolic alkalosis with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L) and is associated with hypertension due to mineralocorticoid excess, which is inconsistent with this patient’s low blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:


Metabolic alkalosis with low urinary chloride (< 20 mEq/L) is a hallmark of chloride-responsive alkalosis, commonly caused by vomiting or diuretic use. Alkalosis-induced hypocalcemia can lead to symptoms like paresthesias and perioral tingling.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe weakness and a long-standing history of dry mouth and dry eyes. His lab results are as follows:

 

  • Serum Sodium (S. Na): 140 mEq/L
  • Serum Potassium (S. K): 1.8 mEq/L
  • Serum Chloride (S. Cl): 115 mEq/L
  • Serum Bicarbonate (S. HCO₃): 12 mEq/L
  • Urinary Sodium (Urinary Na): 25 mEq/L
  • Urinary Potassium (Urinary K): 10 mEq/L
  • Urinary Chloride (Urinary Cl): 20 mEq/L

 

What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distal RTA

 

Option B:

 

The patient presents with severe hypokalemia (S. K = 1.8 mEq/L) and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (low bicarbonate and hyperchloremia). Calculation of the urinary anion gap (UAG) further supports the diagnosis.

 

The urinary anion gap is calculated as:

UAG=(Urinary Na⁺+Urinary K⁺)−Urinary Cl⁻

UAG=(25+10)−20=+15 mEq/L

 

A positive UAG suggests reduced ammonium (NH₄⁺) excretion, which is characteristic of distal renal tubular acidosis (type 1 RTA). This occurs because distal RTA involves an inability of the distal tubules to acidify urine, leading to impaired NH₄⁺ excretion and a positive UAG. The autoimmune symptoms (dry mouth, dry eyes) strongly suggest Sjögren syndrome, a common cause of distal RTA.

 

Causes of Positive and Negative UAG

 

  • Positive UAG: Indicates impaired NH₄⁺ excretion, as seen in distal RTA, type 4 RTA (due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance). 
  • Negative UAG: Indicates intact renal acidification and high NH₄⁺ excretion, as seen in gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss (e.g., diarrhea, enterocutaneous fistulas) and proximal RTA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proximal RTA: Causes bicarbonate wasting and is associated with a negative UAG. Hypokalemia is usually milder. 


Option C. Addison Disease: Leads to hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency, which is inconsistent with the severe hypokalemia in this case.


Option D. Enterocutaneous Fistula: Causes bicarbonate loss leading to metabolic acidosis but is associated with a negative UAG due to increased NH₄⁺ excretion.

 

Educational Objective:


A positive urinary anion gap in the context of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis indicates impaired renal ammonium excretion, a hallmark of distal RTA. This is a key differentiating feature from gastrointestinal bicarbonate losses, which present with a negative UAG. Recognizing these patterns helps narrow the differential diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents with worsening fever, cough, and dyspnea for the past 2 days. He was started on empirical azithromycin 3 days ago, but his condition has worsened. ABG and lab results are as follows:

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute exacerbation of COPD

 

Option A:

 

This patient's presentation and ABG findings are consistent with acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD).

 

  • pH (7.27): Indicates acidemia.
  • pCO₂ (59 mmHg): Elevated, pointing to respiratory acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate (31 mEq/L): Elevated, consistent with chronic compensation in COPD.

 

The low pH, in the context of chronically compensated hypercapnia (as evidenced by elevated bicarbonate), suggests an acute respiratory acidosis due to AECOPD. The hypoxemia (pO₂ 55 mmHg) further supports a decompensated state.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis: Chronic respiratory acidosis is expected in stable COPD patients with compensated hypercapnia. However, the low pH in this patient indicates an acute decompensation.


Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis: Pure acute respiratory acidosis would not explain the elevated bicarbonate, which reflects chronic compensation in COPD.


Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism typically causes respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation, with low pCO₂ levels, not the hypercapnia seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


In a patient with known COPD, a low pH with elevated pCO₂ and bicarbonate indicates acute respiratory acidosis superimposed on chronic compensation, suggesting acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD). Prompt recognition and treatment of the underlying cause, such as infection, are critical.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old pregnant woman (30 weeks gestation) has been diagnosed with pneumonia. She is currently receiving high-flow oxygen with an FiO₂ of 0.5. Her ABG and lab results are as follows:

 

  • pH: 7.42
  • pCO₂: 29 mmHg
  • HCO₃⁻: 20 mmol/L
  • Base Excess: -5.1 mmol/L
  • pO₂: 123 mmHg
  • O₂ Saturation: 99%
  • Potassium: 3.0 mmol/L
  • Sodium: 133 mmol/L
  • Chloride: 109 mmol/L

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 respiratory failure

 

Option B:

 

The patient's hypoxemia (low pO₂) with a normal pCO₂ indicates Type 1 respiratory failure, which is commonly caused by V/Q mismatch. This is confirmed by calculating the A-a gradient:

 

  • A-a gradient calculation:
    • PAO₂ = FiO₂ × (760 - 47) - (pCO₂ / 0.8)
    • PAO₂ = 0.5 × (760 - 47) - (29 / 0.8)
    • PAO₂ = 356.5 - 36.25 = 320.25 mmHg
    • A-a gradient = PAO₂ - PaO₂ = 320.25 - 123 = 197.25 mmHg

 

An A-a gradient >30 mmHg is elevated and a response to O2 (Fio2 50%) is consistent with a V/Q mismatch. Pneumonia is a common cause of Type 1 respiratory failure due to alveolar filling impairing gas exchange. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): While ARDS can cause Type 1 respiratory failure, it typically presents with severe hypoxemia and bilateral infiltrates, and patients would not respond to 100% O2 due to significant shunting. 

 

Option C. Alveolar hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypercapnia (elevated pCO₂), which is not present in this patient.


Option D. Type 4 respiratory failure: Type 4 failure refers to hypoperfusion due to circulatory failure (e.g., septic shock), which is not indicated by the patient's ABG or clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Type 1 respiratory failure is characterized by hypoxemia with a normal or low pCO₂ and is caused by V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, or shunting. An elevated A-a gradient with a good response to supplemental oxygen suggests V/Q mismatch, commonly seen in pneumonia.
